segments.en: Linked Discourses 35
11. Sanctuary
105. Because of Grasping

segments.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati kiṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti?
segments.en: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
“Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

segments.pli: “Cakkhusmiṃ kho, bhikkhave, sati cakkhuṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ … pe …
segments.en: “Mendicants, when there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye, pleasure and pain arise in oneself. …

segments.pli: manasmiṃ sati manaṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ.
segments.en: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.
What do you think, mendicants?
Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
“Impermanent, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
“Suffering, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyya ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti?
segments.en: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
“No, sir.” …
“Is the ear … nose … tongue … body …

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
“Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyya ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti?

segments.en: mind permanent or impermanent?”
“Impermanent, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
“Suffering, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyya ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti?
segments.en: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
“No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati … pe … manasmimpi nibbindati.
segments.en: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

segments.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
segments.en: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

segments.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
